label: q_ed04_q14_paraphrase
content:
{
  "question_id": "ed04_q14_paraphrase",
  "scope_id": "environmental_drift_04",
  "checkpoint_after": 25,
  "question_type": "paraphrase",
  "prompt": "Why is chromium elevated at some stations but not others?",
  "ground_truth": {
    "canonical_answer": "An unpermitted industrial discharge between WQ-02 and WQ-03. Upstream stations remain clean while WQ-03 shows peak concentrations and downstream stations show progressive dilution. Agricultural runoff explains turbidity spikes but not the chromium gradient.",
    "required_evidence_refs": [
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_011",
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_017",
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_024",
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_015"
    ],
    "key_facts": [
      "progressive chromium concentration decay from peak station to downstream sites indicates single-source contamination",
      "discharge source identifiable between last clean upstream station and first elevated station in monitoring network",
      "stations upstream of the anomaly source maintain background-level trace metal readings throughout the study",
      "seasonal nutrient loading explains turbidity spikes but not hexavalent metal signature"
    ]
  }
}
